clinical_study.brief_title: Study Evaluating The Safety And Efficacy Of Varenicline and Bupropion For Smoking Cessation In Subjects With And Without A History Of Psychiatric Disorders
clinical_study.official_title: A Phase 4, Randomized, Double-blind, Active And Placebo-controlled, Multicenter Study Evaluating The Neuropsychiatric Safety And Efficacy Of 12 Weeks Varenicline Tartrate 1mg Bid And Bupropion Hydrochloride 150mg Bid For Smoking Cessation In Subjects With And Without A History Of Psychiatric Disorders

brief_summary.textblock: This study is being conducted to assess varenicline and bupropion as aids to smoking cessation treatment in subjects with and without an established diagnosis of major psychiatric disorder and to characterize the neuropsychiatric safety profile (pre-specified adverse events (AEs) in both of these populations).

primary_outcome.measure: Occurrence of Neuropsychiatric (NPS) Adverse Events (AE) - the Primary Study Endpoint
primary_outcome.time_frame: Treatment emergent is first dose date to last dose date (up to 12 weeks) plus 30 days.
primary_outcome.description: The primary safety endpoint is the occurrence of at least one treatment emergent "severe" adverse event of anxiety, depression, feeling abnormal, or hostility and/or the occurrence of at least one treatment emergent "moderate" or "severe" adverse event of: agitation, aggression, delusions, hallucinations, homicidal ideation, mania, panic, paranoia, psychosis, suicidal ideation, suicidal behavior, or completed suicide.

primary_outcome.measure: Estimated NPS AE Rate (%), by Cohort
primary_outcome.time_frame: Treatment emergent is first dose date to last dose date (up to 12 weeks) plus 30 days.
primary_outcome.description: The primary safety endpoint is the occurrence of at least one treatment emergent "severe" adverse event of anxiety, depression, feeling abnormal, or hostility and/or the occurrence of at least one treatment emergent "moderate" or "severe" adverse event of: agitation, aggression, delusions, hallucinations, homicidal ideation, mania, panic, paranoia, psychosis, suicidal ideation, suicidal behavior, or completed suicide. Estimated NPS AE rate (%) was calculated based on least-squares means analysis.

secondary_outcome.measure: Occurrence of the Components of the NPS AE Primary Endpoint, Non-psychiatric History Cohort
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Treatment emergent is first dose date to last dose date (up to 12 weeks) plus 30 days.
secondary_outcome.description: The safety endpoint is the occurrence of at least one treatment emergent "severe" adverse event of anxiety, depression, feeling abnormal, or hostility and/or the occurrence of at least one treatment emergent "moderate" or "severe" adverse event of: agitation, aggression, delusions, hallucinations, homicidal ideation, mania, panic, paranoia, psychosis, suicidal ideation, suicidal behavior, or completed suicide. Each of these 16 components is reported below.

secondary_outcome.measure: Occurrence of the Components of the NPS AE Primary Endpoint, Psychiatric History Cohort
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Treatment emergent is first dose date to last dose date (up to 12 weeks) plus 30 days.

Each of these 16 components is reported below.

secondary_outcome.measure: Occurrence of the Components of NPS AE Primary Endpoint (Overall)
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Treatment emergent is first dose date to last dose date (up to 12 weeks) plus 30 days.
secondary_outcome.description: The NPS AE composite results (as previously described) are for the two cohorts combined and are presented below.

secondary_outcome.measure: Occurrence of Severe-only NPS AEs in the Primary Endpoint, by Cohort
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Treatment emergent is first dose date to last dose date (up to 12 weeks) plus 30 days.
secondary_outcome.description: The primary safety endpoint is the occurrence of at least one treatment emergent "severe" adverse event of anxiety, depression, feeling abnormal, or hostility and/or the occurrence of at least one treatment emergent "moderate" or "severe" adverse event of: agitation, aggression, delusions, hallucinations, homicidal ideation, mania, panic, paranoia, psychosis, suicidal ideation, suicidal behavior, or completed suicide. Only those events rated as severe are reported; this excludes any moderate events in the primary NPS AE endpoint.

Only those events rated as severe are reported; this excludes any moderate events in the primary NPS AE endpoint.

secondary_outcome.measure: Hospital Anxiety and Depression Scale (HADS) Total Score, Non-psychiatric History Cohort
secondary_outcome.description: The HADS is a subject self-reporting scale completed in person at clinic visits at Baseline and Weeks 1 through 6, 8, 10, 12, 13, 16, 20, and 24. It contains 14 individual item responses ranging in increasing severity from 0 (normal) to 3 (most severe) for a total range of 0 to 42. Of the 14 items, 7 assess anxiety and 7 assess depression, providing 2 subscales with ranges of 0 to 21. For each subscale, 0 to 7 is considered normal, while 15 to 21 represents severe symptoms.

secondary_outcome.measure: Positive Responses for Suicidal Behavior and/or Ideation by Columbia Suicide Severity Rating Scale (C‑SSRS) - Non-psychiatric History Cohort
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Lifetime, Baseline and Treatment-Emergent is first dose date to last dose date (up to 12 weeks) plus 30 days.
secondary_outcome.description: The C-SSRS is a semi-structured interview designed to evaluate an individual's degree of suicidal ideation, preparatory acts or behavior to actual attempt, ranging from "wish to be dead" to "active suicidal ideation with specific plan and intent". Answers at screening are for lifetime history. Answers for all other visits are since last visit.The scale is also used to record any completed suicides.

secondary_outcome.measure: Positive Responses for Suicidal Behavior and/or Ideation by Columbia Suicide Severity Rating Scale (C‑SSRS) - Psychiatric History Cohort

secondary_outcome.measure: Clinical Global Impression of Improvement (CGI‑I), "No Change" Rating by Visit
secondary_outcome.description: The CGI-I is a clinician rated instrument that measures change in participant's psychiatric condition (or lack thereof in the stratum without psychiatric disorders) on a 7 point scale ranging from 1 (very much improved) to 7 (very much worse), with 4 = no change. The ratings were applicable even to those without psychiatric diagnoses (eg, those with no psychiatric symptoms would be rated as "normal, not at all ill" on the CGI-S at baseline and assuming no psychiatric symptoms emerge during the trial, would be rated as "no change" on the CGI-I at follow-up visits). For those participants with a psychiatric diagnosis, the clinician should rate the severity of the mental illness with respect to the clinician's experience with the psychiatric population to which the participant belongs.

secondary_outcome.measure: CO‑Confirmed Continuous Abstinence for Weeks 9 Through 12, Non-psychiatric History Cohort
secondary_outcome.description: A responder to this endpoint requires the answer "no" to both questions 1 and 2 on the Nicotine Use Inventory at every visit from Week 9 to Week 12 (inclusive).

secondary_outcome.measure: CO‑Confirmed Continuous Abstinence for Weeks 9 Through 12, Psychiatric History Cohort
secondary_outcome.description: A responder to this endpoint requires the answer "no" to both questions 1 and 2 on the Nicotine Use Inventory at every visit from Week 9 to Week 12 (inclusive).

secondary_outcome.description: A responder to this endpoint requires the answer "no" to both questions 1 and 2 on the Nicotine Use Inventory at every visit from Week 9 to Week 12 (inclusive).

secondary_outcome.measure: CO-confirmed Continuous Abstinence From Week 9 Through Week 24, Non-psychiatric History Cohort
secondary_outcome.description: A responder to this endpoint requires the answer "no" to both questions 1 and 2 on the Nicotine Use Inventory at every visit from Week 9 to Week 24 (inclusive).

secondary_outcome.measure: CO-confirmed Continuous Abstinence From Week 9 Through Week 24 (Overall)
secondary_outcome.description: A responder to this endpoint requires the answer "no" to both questions 1 and 2 on the Nicotine Use Inventory at every visit from Week 9 to Week 24 (inclusive).

secondary_outcome.measure: 7‑Day Point Prevalence of Abstinence, Non-psychiatric History Cohort
secondary_outcome.description: A responder to this endpoint requires the answer "no" to both questions 3 and 6 on the nicotine use inventory at that specific visit. NUI Question 3 (Baseline through Week 24): Has the subject smoked any cigarettes (even a puff) in the last 7 days? NUI Question 6 (Baseline through Week 12): Has the subject used any other nicotine containing products in the last 7 days? NUI Question 6 (Week 13 through Week 24): Has the subject used any other tobacco products in the last 7 days?

secondary_outcome.measure: 7‑Day Point Prevalence of Abstinence, Psychiatric History Cohort
secondary_outcome.description: A responder to this endpoint requires the answer "no" to both questions 3 and 6 on the nicotine use inventory at that specific visit. NUI Question 3 (Baseline through Week 24): Has the subject smoked any cigarettes (even a puff) in the last 7 days? NUI Question 6 (Baseline through Week 12): Has the subject used any other nicotine containing products in the last 7 days? NUI Question 6 (Week 13 through Week 24): Has the subject used any other tobacco products in the last 7 days?

secondary_outcome.measure: 7‑Day Point Prevalence of Abstinence (Overall)
secondary_outcome.description: A responder to this endpoint requires the answer "no" to both questions 3 and 6 on the nicotine use inventory at that specific visit. NUI Question 3 (Baseline through Week 24): Has the subject smoked any cigarettes (even a puff) in the last 7 days? NUI Question 6 (Baseline through Week 12): Has the subject used any other nicotine containing products in the last 7 days? arm_group.description: Subjects randomized to placebo will receive placebo treatments for all three study drugs. Blinded placebo will be provided for varenicline, bupropion hydrochloride and transdermal nicotine patch (NRT). In addition, subjects will receive blinded placebo treatments for the study drugs they are not randomized to receive.

intervention.description: Triple dummy placebo for each treatment arm
Subjects will be titrated to the full dose during the first week in the following manner: 0.5 mg (tablet form) once a day for 3 days, 0.5 mg twice a day for 4 days, then 1 mg twice a day for 11 weeks
Subjects will receive 150 mg (tablet form) once a day for 3 days and then will take 150 mg twice a day for the remainder of the treatment period (11 weeks and 4 days).

Subjects will start active dosing the morning of the Week 1 visit and will receive a 21 mg transdermal patch per day x 7 weeks, followed by a 14 mg transdermal patch per day x 2 weeks, and then a 7 mg transdermal patch x 2 weeks for a total of 11 weeks of treatment.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Male or female cigarette smokers, 18- 75 years, motivated to stop smoking and considered suitable for a smoking cessation attempt.
- Smoked an average of at least 10 cigarettes per day during past year and during the month prior to the screening visit, and exhaled carbon monoxide (CO) >10 ppm at screening.
- For Neuropsychiatric cohort- subjects must have proper diagnosis as outlined in protocol.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Subjects with a past or current diagnosis of one of the following disorders:
a. Psychotic Disorders:
- Schizophreniform
- Delusional Disorder
- Psychotic Disorder NOS b. All Delirium, Dementia, and Amnestic and Other Cognitive Disorders c. All Substance Induced Disorders (Other than nicotine)

participant_flow.recruitment_details: A total of 11,186 participants were screened for participation in the study, of which 3042 participants were considered to be screen failures, leaving 8144 participants eligible for study participation (efficacy population). 86 participants (1.1%) did not receive study drug. A total of 8058 participants received study drug (safety population).
participant_flow.pre_assignment_details: Participants were classified into 2 cohorts: participants without diagnosis of psychiatric disorder and participants with a stable diagnosis of psychiatric disorder confirmed by the Structured Clinical Interview for the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (SCID) 4th edition conducted at screening.

group.title: Varenicline
group.description: Participants were randomized to 1 of the 3 active dosing groups that took active medication of either varenicline, bupropion, NRT in this triple-dummy design. Participants in this arm received varenicline titrated to the full dose during the first week in the following manner: 0.5 mg daily once (QD) x 3 days, 0.5 mg twice daily (BID) x 4 days, then 1 mg BID for 11 weeks. They also received placebo bupropion and NRT patch, dosed in the same manner as the active medication.

group.title: Bupropion
group.description: Participants were randomized to 1 of the 3 active dosing groups that took active medication of either varenicline, bupropion, NRT in this triple-dummy design. Participants in this arm received bupropion 150 mg QD x 3 days and taken 150 mg BID for the remainder of the treatment period (11 weeks and 4 days). They also received placebo varenicline and NRT patch, dosed in the same manner as the active medication.

group.title: NRT Patch
group.description: Participants were randomized to 1 of the 3 active dosing groups that took active medication of either varenicline, bupropion, NRT in this triple-dummy design. Participants in this arm received NRT started active dosing the morning of the Week 1 visit and received a 21 mg transdermal patch per day x 7 weeks, followed by a 14 mg transdermal patch per day x 2 weeks, and then a 7 mg transdermal patch x 2 weeks for a total of 11 weeks of treatment. They also received placebo varenicline and bupropion, dosed in the same manner as active medication.

group.title: Placebo
group.description: Participants received matching placebo for varenicline, bupropion, and NRT in this triple-dummy design, and followed the same titration and dosing schedule as for the active treatments noted above.

baseline.population: The safety analysis population contained all treated participants i.e. who received at least one partial dose of study medication.

analysis.groups_desc: The reduced (final) statistical model included treatment group, cohort and region, plus the 2-way interaction of treatment by cohort. Other interactions not included due to lack of significance. Region reduced to 2-level to address event sparseness issue.
analysis.p_value_desc: An interaction between treatment and cohort was considered significant at 10% level. No multiplicity adjustments were utilized.
analysis.method_desc: A generalized linear regression analysis based on the safety analysis set was used to evaluate incidence of NPS AE as the primary analysis.

Estimated NPS AE rate (%) was calculated based on least-squares means analysis.

outcome.title: Occurrence of the Components of the NPS AE Primary Endpoint, Non-psychiatric History Cohort
outcome.description: The safety endpoint is the occurrence of at least one treatment emergent “severe” adverse event of anxiety, depression, feeling abnormal, or hostility and/or the occurrence of at least one treatment emergent “moderate” or “severe” adverse event of: agitation, aggression, delusions, hallucinations, homicidal ideation, mania, panic, paranoia, psychosis, suicidal ideation, suicidal behavior, or completed suicide. Each of these 16 components is reported below.
outcome.time_frame: Treatment emergent is first dose date to last dose date (up to 12 weeks) plus 30 days.
outcome.population: The safety dataset included all participants who had received at least one partial dose of study medication (N=8058) and was used to analyze all safety endpoints.

group.title: Varenicline 1.0 mg BID
group.description: Participants were randomized to 1 of the 3 active dosing groups that took active medication of either varenicline, bupropion, NRT in this triple-dummy design. Participants in this arm received varenicline titrated to the full dose during the first week in the following manner: 0.5 mg QD x 3 days, 0.5 mg BID x 4 days, then 1 mg BID for 11 weeks. They also received placebo bupropion and NRT patch, dosed in the same manner as the active medication.

group.title: Bupropion 150 mg BID
group.description: Participants were randomized to 1 of the 3 active dosing groups that took active medication of either varenicline, bupropion, NRT in this triple-dummy design. Participants in this arm received bupropion 150 mg QD x 3 days and taken 150 mg BID for the remainder of the treatment period (11 weeks and 4 days). They also received placebo varenicline and NRT patch, dosed in the same manner as the active medication.

group.title: NRT Patch
group.description: Participants were randomized to 1 of the 3 active dosing groups that took active medication of either varenicline, bupropion, NRT in this triple-dummy design. Participants in this arm received NRT started active dosing the morning of the Week 1 visit and received a 21 mg transdermal patch per day x 7 weeks, followed by a 14 mg transdermal patch per day x 2 weeks, and then a 7 mg transdermal patch x 2 weeks for a total of 11 weeks of treatment. They also received placebo varenicline and bupropion, dosed in the same manner as active medication.

group.title: Placebo
group.description: Participants received matching placebo for varenicline, bupropion, and NRT in this triple-dummy design, and followed the same titration and dosing schedule as for the active treatments noted above.

measure.title: Occurrence of the Components of the NPS AE Primary Endpoint, Non-psychiatric History Cohort

outcome.title: Hospital Anxiety and Depression Scale (HADS) Total Score, Non-psychiatric History Cohort
outcome.description: The HADS is a subject self-reporting scale completed in person at clinic visits at Baseline and Weeks 1 through 6, 8, 10, 12, 13, 16, 20, and 24. It contains 14 individual item responses ranging in increasing severity from 0 (normal) to 3 (most severe) for a total range of 0 to 42. Of the 14 items, 7 assess anxiety and 7 assess depression, providing 2 subscales with ranges of 0 to 21. For each subscale, 0 to 7 is considered normal, while 15 to 21 represents severe symptoms.
outcome.population: The safety dataset included all participants who had received at least one partial dose of study medication (N=8058) and was used to analyze all safety endpoints.

It contains 14 individual item responses ranging in increasing severity from 0 (normal) to 3 (most severe) for a total range of 0 to 42. Of the 14 items, 7 assess anxiety and 7 assess depression, providing 2 subscales with ranges of 0 to 21. For each subscale, 0 to 7 is considered normal, while 15 to 21 represents severe symptoms.
measure.population: The safety dataset included all participants who had received at least one partial dose of study medication (N=8058) and was used to analyze all safety endpoints.

outcome.title: Positive Responses for Suicidal Behavior and/or Ideation by Columbia Suicide Severity Rating Scale (C‑SSRS) - Non-psychiatric History Cohort
outcome.description: The C-SSRS is a semi-structured interview designed to evaluate an individual's degree of suicidal ideation, preparatory acts or behavior to actual attempt, ranging from "wish to be dead" to "active suicidal ideation with specific plan and intent". Answers at screening are for lifetime history. Answers for all other visits are since last visit.The scale is also used to record any completed suicides.
outcome.time_frame: Lifetime, Baseline and Treatment-Emergent is first dose date to last dose date (up to 12 weeks) plus 30 days.
outcome.population: The safety dataset included all participants who had received at least one partial dose of study medication (N=8058) and was used to analyze all safety endpoints.

group.title: Varenicline 1.0 mg BID
group.description: Participants were randomized to 1 of the 3 active dosing groups that took active medication of either varenicline, bupropion, NRT in this triple-dummy design. Participants in this arm received varenicline titrated to the full dose during the first week in the following manner: 0.5 mg QD x 3 days, 0.5 mg BID x 4 days, then 1 mg BID for 11 weeks. They also received placebo bupropion and NRT patch, dosed in the same manner as the active medication.

group.title: Bupropion 150 mg BID
group.description: Participants were randomized to 1 of the 3 active dosing groups that took active medication of either varenicline, bupropion, NRT in this triple-dummy design. Participants in this arm received bupropion 150 mg QD x 3 days and taken 150 mg BID for the remainder of the treatment period (11 weeks and 4 days). They also received placebo varenicline and NRT patch, dosed in the same manner as the active medication.

group.title: NRT Patch
group.description: Participants were randomized to 1 of the 3 active dosing groups that took active medication of either varenicline, bupropion, NRT in this triple-dummy design. Participants in this arm received NRT started active dosing the morning of the Week 1 visit and received a 21 mg transdermal patch per day x 7 weeks, followed by a 14 mg transdermal patch per day x 2 weeks, and then a 7 mg transdermal patch x 2 weeks for a total of 11 weeks of treatment. They also received placebo varenicline and bupropion, dosed in the same manner as active medication.

group.title: Placebo
group.description: Participants received matching placebo for varenicline, bupropion, and NRT in this triple-dummy design, and followed the same titration and dosing schedule as for the active treatments noted above.

measure.title: Positive Responses for Suicidal Behavior and/or Ideation by Columbia Suicide Severity Rating Scale (C‑SSRS) - Non-psychiatric History Cohort
measure.description: The C-SSRS is a semi-structured interview designed to evaluate an individual's degree of suicidal ideation, preparatory acts or behavior to actual attempt, ranging from "wish to be dead" to "active suicidal ideation with specific plan and intent". Answers at screening are for lifetime history. Answers for all other visits are since last visit.The scale is also used to record any completed suicides.

outcome.title: Clinical Global Impression of Improvement (CGI‑I), "No Change" Rating by Visit
outcome.description: The CGI-I is a clinician rated instrument that measures change in participant's psychiatric condition (or lack thereof in the stratum without psychiatric disorders) on a 7 point scale ranging from 1 (very much improved) to 7 (very much worse), with 4 = no change. The ratings were applicable even to those without psychiatric diagnoses (eg, those with no psychiatric symptoms would be rated as "normal, not at all ill" on the CGI-S at baseline and assuming no psychiatric symptoms emerge during the trial, would be rated as "no change" on the CGI-I at follow-up visits). For those participants with a psychiatric diagnosis, the clinician should rate the severity of the mental illness with respect to the clinician's experience with the psychiatric population to which the participant belongs.
outcome.population: The safety dataset included all participants who had received at least one partial dose of study medication (N=8058) and was used to analyze all safety endpoints.

outcome.title: CO‑Confirmed Continuous Abstinence for Weeks 9 Through 12, Non-psychiatric History Cohort
outcome.description: A responder to this endpoint requires the answer “no” to both questions 1 and 2 on the Nicotine Use Inventory at every visit from Week 9 to Week 12 (inclusive).
outcome.population: The full analysis set was defined under the intent-to-treat (ITT) principle as all randomized participants (N=8144) and was used for all efficacy endpoints.

measure.title: CO-confirmed Continuous Abstinence From Week 9 Through Week 24 (Overall)
measure.description: A responder to this endpoint requires the answer “no” to both questions 1 and 2 on the Nicotine Use Inventory at every visit from Week 9 to Week 24 (inclusive).
measure.population: The full analysis set was defined under the ITT principle as all randomized participants (N=8144) and was used for all efficacy endpoints.

analysis.groups_desc: The analysis was done using a logistic regression with terms treatment and region. Region reduced to 2-level for consistency with primary safety model.
The analysis was done using a logistic regression with terms treatment and region. Region reduced to 2-level for consistency with primary safety model.
The analysis was done using a logistic regression with terms treatment and region. Region reduced to 2-level for consistency with primary safety model.

outcome.title: 7‑Day Point Prevalence of Abstinence, Non-psychiatric History Cohort
outcome.description: A responder to this endpoint requires the answer “no” to both questions 3 and 6 on the nicotine use inventory at that specific visit. NUI Question 3 (Baseline through Week 24): Has the subject smoked any cigarettes (even a puff) in the last 7 days? NUI Question 6 (Baseline through Week 12): Has the subject used any other nicotine containing products in the last 7 days? NUI Question 6 (Week 13 through Week 24): Has the subject used any other tobacco products in the last 7 days?
outcome.population: The full analysis set was defined under the ITT principle as all randomized participants (N=8144) and was used for all efficacy endpoints.

group.title: Varenicline 1.0 mg BID
group.description: Participants were randomized to 1 of the 3 active dosing groups that took active medication of either varenicline, bupropion, NRT in this triple-dummy design. Participants in this arm received varenicline titrated to the full dose during the first week in the following manner: 0.5 mg QD x 3 days, 0.5 mg BID x 4 days, then 1 mg BID for 11 weeks. They also received placebo bupropion and NRT patch, dosed in the same manner as the active medication.

group.title: Bupropion 150 mg BID
group.description: Participants were randomized to 1 of the 3 active dosing groups that took active medication of either varenicline, bupropion, NRT in this triple-dummy design. Participants in this arm received bupropion 150 mg QD x 3 days and taken 150 mg BID for the remainder of the treatment period (11 weeks and 4 days). They also received placebo varenicline and NRT patch, dosed in the same manner as the active medication.

group.title: NRT Patch
group.description: Participants were randomized to 1 of the 3 active dosing groups that took active medication of either varenicline, bupropion, NRT in this triple-dummy design. Participants in this arm received NRT started active dosing the morning of the Week 1 visit and received a 21 mg transdermal patch per day x 7 weeks, followed by a 14 mg transdermal patch per day x 2 weeks, and then a 7 mg transdermal patch x 2 weeks for a total of 11 weeks of treatment. They also received placebo varenicline and bupropion, dosed in the same manner as active medication.

reported_events.time_frame: From baseline throughout the study period (16 weeks). Treatment emergent is first dose date to last dose date (up to 12 weeks) plus 30 days.
reported_events.desc: AEs were reported from the time the informed consent was signed throughout the study including 30 days after the last dose of study medication. In addition to the the standard collection of volunteered and observed AEs, neuropsychiatric AEs of interest were solicited using the Neuropsychiatric Adverse Event Interview.

event.sub_title: Infective exacerbation of chronic obstructive airways disease

category.title: Neoplasms benign, malignant and unspecified (incl cysts and polyps)

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: Sponsor has the right to review disclosures, requesting a delay of less than 60 days. Investigator will postpone single center publications until after disclosure of pooled data (all sites), less than 12 months from study participating sites. Investigator may not disclose previously undisclosed confidential other than study results.

clinical_results.limitations_and_caveats: After database lock and unblinding, one additional participant in the NRT arm of psychiatric cohort was found who had a primary endpoint event (moderate suicidal ideation) which required hospitalization; this event is not included in any analyses.
